div.head: The Third ACT.
div.stage: Enter Crazy and Drybob with their Swords drawn.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: COme, come, have you made your Will?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Yes, yes, don't you trouble your self for that, I have it alwayes ready upon these occasions.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: If you have not, your Estate by being unsettled, may come to be divided among the Lawyers, after I have kill'd you.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Sweet. Mr. Crazy, don't think to fright me, for I am a Rhinoceros, if I care any more for you than I do for a Feather of a Shuttlecock.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: This will not fright the Rogue.—
Under favour I will run you thorow the Lungs immediately.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: He shall not out-huffe me—
Look you Sir, I am no man to be frighted, though you look as big as a Dutch Trumpeter; and I think that's well enough said too.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I am no Gentleman, if I do not stick you to the ground the first Pass.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: I am the Son of a Corn-Cutter if I do not rip up your Puddens instantly. Death this Rogue looks like a very Bussy d' Ambois.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p:
Come on Sir, have at you— yet if you will resign
Theodosia, I care not, if I be contented with a Leg or an Arm; not that I believe you have an interest; but for form sake.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Resign my Mistriss! ha, ha, if I should, do you think she would marry a Fellow with a face that looks like a squeez'd Turnip; and I think there's a Satyrical Bob upon you.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I must try some other way.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Why you look already as sowrely as the Picture of a Stabb'd Lucrece. I shall break the Rogues heart with these Bobs.
sp.stage: [Craz. beats Dryb. Sword out of his hand, before he is aware on't.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Now Sir, pray quickly.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I cannot pray very well, but I can run as well as most men in the Nation, which will serve my turn better at this time—

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Are you so nimble, I shall overtake you; 'Slife this Rogue has run his heats at New Market I think—
sp.stage: [Dryb. runs round the Stage and Crazy after him—

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: This is a lucky opportunity:
sp.stage: [Craz. lets fall one of the Swords.
Entèr Mrs. Friske passing slowly over the Stage—

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I say; I'll spare your life two minutes, till I wait upon you, Lady.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: You spare my life! I scorn your words; but I will in mercy let you take your leave of her; since 'tis the last time you shall ever see her.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Ah— what's here, a Sword drawn—

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Be not afraid, Madam Frisk, I am fighting with a simple fellow here for your honour.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: For my honour? I was going to Mr. Brisk's Lodging, I'll call him to help you.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: By no means. Dear Madam Friske let me kiss but this fair hand, and that will inspire me to kill twenty such Rascals in an Afternoon.— But where shall I have the honour to wait upon you by and by?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Put up your Sword then, I will be at my Lodging within a quarter of an hour, and I shall have never a friend with me.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: What will you ne'r have done there?

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Madam, I will but run this Fellow thorow the Body a little, and I'll not fail to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: If I fall on now I shall come off with honour, for she'll be sure to call some body to part us.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Help, help, Mr. Briske. Oh help, help Mr. Briske.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Stand your ground you Coxcomb, do you think I am bound to fight you by the mile.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: There, I dare not stay to look on them—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Hold, hold! What a pox ails you? Hold, hold, you Wits can never agree among your selves; you are not so strong a Party, that you should need to destroy one another: you are fighting here as fiercely as Guy of Warwick and Colbrand the Dane.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Faith Jack Briske that's a pretty thought of thine, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Put up, for shame, put up, and be Pilades and Orestes, what was your quarrel? I am afraid you do not understand these nice points of honour. Let me hear, how was it?

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: He had the insolence obliquely to give me the Name of Son of a Bitch.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: I protest and vow he gaue me the ignominious appellation of a Dog, like a damn'd Cynick Phylosopher.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Why look you, here's your mistake already: Why I was call'd Son of a Whore at Chatolins last night, and what do you think I did?

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: According to the Laws of honour I make no question.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: P'shaw, you understand those things no more than a Costermonger.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Pish, you are out, you are out! Lord. Lord, To see the fault of mens Education. I'll tell you— when he call'd me Son of a Whore, I ev'n took him up roundly, and told him flat and plain I scorn'd his words. Now by this means I put this Rogue out of his Road; the Sot knew not what to reply, I took such a new way of affronting him.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: This fellow is no better than a Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: I am the Son of a Squirrel, if this was not mighty pretty and exotick.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ay, was't not, I knew I should vex the heart of him with this affront, and upon my honour it incens'd him so devillishly, that ha, ha, ha— he gave me three as good sufficient substantial kicks as a man would wish to see in a Summers day, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: But what didst thou reply to the kicks, Jack, ha?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Why faith when he kick'd me, I told him very smartly, I scorn'd such ill-bred Sots from my heart, and that I thought him as much below me as the fellow that cries Tinder-Boxes and Mouse-Trapps; and then sung a Corant of Berkenshawes in D'sol, re, fa, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: By Gayland Ben. Buker, and Taffaletta, most judiciously manag'd.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: At this he was amaz'd, and said I was a Stoick, but I sung on, fa la, la, la, which by the way is an excellent Corant, thou shalt hear't, fa la, la.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: In good faith it is a very merry and luscious Corant.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: But come, my dear friends, embrace, embrace.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Sir, under favour, I do no more care for him, than I do for one of your Operators for Teeth.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Nor I for you, any more than for one of those obstreperous wide-mouth'd Rogues that cry Spratts, which I think by the way is another guess thought than yours, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Come, upon my honour you shall embrace; and I will bring you to my Mistriss, and we'll have Fiddles and dance too.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Nay, if there be a Lady in the Case I submit.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: And what care I, no body shall bee too hard for me in kindness.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Your Servant, Mr. Drybob.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Your humble Servant Mr. Crazy.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: So come, let's go to my Mistriss, fa la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: This was a lucky ●… ' ancounter—

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Good Mr. Sneake, you will overset me with Learning, you smell so strong of the University.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Truly Mrs. Bridget, by the interposition of an Opacous distance between those Luminaries your Eyes and my self, I have suffer'd a Deliquium, viz. an Eclipse.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: You have not, I deny your Major.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I could delucidate this by way of illustration, but I confess Metaphors are not argumentive; but your Eyes I say are like the Birds in the Hyrcinian Groves, which by the refulgency of their Wings did guid the wandring Traveller, and enlighten the most Opacous tenebrosity.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: So much for this time, yonder comes a stranger, we will retire.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I am your Servant in any thing within the Sphere of my Activity

div.stage: Enter Sir Richard Loveyouth in disguise.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Who's this—

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: You shall have conference with her, I will cause her to approach incontinently.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: What Coxcomb have we got here? well this disguise and my long absence will secure me from my Wives knowledge, I am resolv'd to try her farther. 'Tis possible that impertinence, that vanity and frowardness, that made me leave her, by this time may have forsaken her— Here she comes. I'll observe her.
Madam, Are you my Lady Loveyouth.

sp.speaker: La. Lovey.
sp.p: I am, would you have any thing with me?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I am the unhappy Messenger of ill news to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: La. Lovey.
sp.p: Ill news? What can that be?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Your Husband, Sir Richard Loveyouth.

sp.speaker: La. Love.
sp.p: My Husband! What of him? I hope he is not living yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Madam, He is dead.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Dead! and how dy'd he?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: He was kill'd in Candia in that fatal Sally made by the French upon the Turks.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Art thou sure of it?

sp.speaker: Sir Ric.
sp.p: This is very fine.
Madam, I brought off his body, having then the honour to be his Servant, and to confirm what I say, behold this Ring of his.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: It is so; but I will not afflict my self farther, we must all die; the grief that was due to his memory, I believing him dead, have paid alteady.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: A very short liv'd grief I thank her for't. Ha! I have a way to make discoveries of her, that may be cause of a Divorce, which Heaven send me. Madam, the death of my Master has put me out of employment, and if your Ladyship has any vacant place, I beg to serve you. I will do it faithfully.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: You speak very seasonably; for my Gentleman-Usher dy'd last week for love of my Shoemakers Daughter, you shall succeed him.

sp.speaker: Sir. Rich.
sp.p: A worthy Employment—
Madam, I humbly thank you.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Much good may it do you, and as a beginning of your service, pray go into the next room, and desire Mr. Raymund, a handsom worthy Gentleman, that waits there, to come to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I will Madam— A very good beginning—

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Now Mr. Raymund I am assur'd of my Husbands death.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: How Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: This honest fellow, whom I have entertain'd into my service, saw him dead. Pray tell him you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: O Devil! what's this?—
'Tis too true Sir.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: And now Sir] I take the liberty to tell you I can no longer be refractory to your honourable desires.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Sir, Here's a Letter for you left by a Porter; who said it requir'd no answer and is gone.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: For me, what can it be?

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Where's my Niece?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: In her Chamber, Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: If she offers to intrude upon Mr. Raymund and my self; tell her we are busie.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I will Madam.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: And do you hear?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Shall I believe my Senses?

I Cannot but be sensible of the honour you do me in your Professions of kindness to me, and since this Paper cannot blush, I presume to tell you what nothing but the restraint I suffer could force me to; which is, that your person and your passion are esteem'd by
You may trust this Bearer.
Theodosia.
Ah my dear Theodosia.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: How now Minx? What makes you sawcily intrude upon Mr. Raymund and me?

sp.speaker: Theo,
sp.p: A certain curiosity of doing things that are forbidden me.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis very well; but pray gape not after him. You may if you please call him Uncle: In the mean time get you in.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Curse on her impertinent Jealousie.
Madam, I have too short a time to tell you how I am transported at your Letter.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Pray take care, we are spy'd; talk with Bridget, I am assur'd of her faith to me.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Good lack! Niece, you might have spoken lowd, Mr. Raymund would have trusted me; but pray get you to your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Well Aunt I shall be quit with you—

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Hark vou Robin.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Mrs. Bridget, since Theodosia has intrusted you, you must not refuse to bring me privately into her Chamber this Night.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I shall be glad to serve you, but my Lady will discover it.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Let me alone to manage that; I'll dispose of her that she shall never know of it.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Mr. Raymund I beg your pardon; but if you please at present we will with-draw.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I'll wait on your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ah Madam! your Ladyships humble Servant.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Gentlemen your Servant.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Where is your Niece?

sp.speaker: La. Lov
sp.p: I'll send her to you—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Now, you shall see my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: This is a very good jest i faith, Crazy; his Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: That men should understand themselves no better?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Fa, la, la, la, that's an excellent Corant; really I must confess Grabu is a very pretty hopeful man, but Berkenshaw is a rare fellow, give him his due, fa la, la, for he can teach men to compose, that are deaf, dumb, and blind.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: This is a good, pretty, apish, docible fellow; really he might have made a very pretty Barber Surgeon, if he had been put out in time: but it arrides me extreamly, to think how he will be bob'd?

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he will be bob'd; that men should be so mistaken.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p:
Ay, on my Conscience and Soul the Palat of 〈◊〉 Judgement
is down; and by the way how do'st like that Metaphor or rather Catachresis?

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Oh admirably.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Drybob.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: While these Coxcombs are in discourse, I'll privately go in and see my Mistriss—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Here's a Perriwig, no Flax in the world can be whiter; how delicately it appears by this Colour'd Hanging, and let me advise you ever while you live, if you have a fair Peruke, get by a Green or some Dark Colour'd Hanging or Curtain, if there be one in the Room. Oh it sets it off admirably.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: A very Metaphysical Notion.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: And be sure if your Eye-brows be not black, to black 'em soundly; ah your Black Eye-brow is your fashionable Eye-brow. I hate Rogues that wear Eye-brows that are out of Fashion.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: By the soul of Gresham a most Phylosophical Invention.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Thou'lt scarce believe it, but upon my honour, two Ladies fell in love with me one day at the Kings Play-House, and are in a desperate condition at this very time, for this Perywig.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: But why are you so cruel?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Alas! if I should mind every Lady that falls in love with me, I should have a fine time on't indeed.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Stultorum omnia plena! I am the spurious issue of a Fishmonger, if a more conceited Puppy ever presented himself to my Eyes.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I had three several Suits in one year won me three very ingenious, quick-spirited, and very pretty merry conceited Ladies as any are within the Walls of Europe. You must know I do value my self upon my Clothes and the judicious wearing of 'em.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Nay certainly you are a most compleat and polite Gentleman in the opinion of at least two besides your self.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: No, no, but I'll tell thee an honest fellow of my acquaintance, by imitating one of my Suits, got himself a 〈◊〉 of 3000 l. a year Peny Rent.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Pray Madam, let me advise you, don't run your self into trouble with these Puppies, but let us enjoy our selves in private.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Sir, I must obey my Aunt, 'tis not for want of Inclination to your sweet Society, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ah, my Queen Regent, I salute the hem of your Garment.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I cannot without a blush, allow the humility of the address.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Thou shalt see Crazy how she'll abuse him, for I am the Son of a Bum-Bayly if she has not the most exuberant and luxurious expressions that ever enter'd the concave of this Ear.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: This Fool Drybob has no more understanding than a Gander.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: By the Coat of our Family, which is an Ass Rampant, a very ancient and honourable one, I am ready to venture my life under the Banner of your Beauty; and honour you so, that I would, oh 'tis incomparable, 'tis incomprehenfible.—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: By my Grandfather's Spur-leather, which was in those dayes worn by very honourable Persons, you oblige me so immoderately: That oh— 'tis admirable, tis inexpressible!

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: How I blush for this fellow!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Come, Madam, let's be frolick, Galliard, and extraordinary brisk, fa, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot behold the lines of that face, but I am provok'd to mirth, fa, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Look you there Drybob and Crazy, look ye—

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Madam, I am so interrupted by these fellows, that I have not time to tell you that I feed a Flame within, which so torments me.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Pox on't that's stole out of a Play.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: What then, that's lawful; 'tis a shifting age for wit, and every body lies upon the Catch.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: O Madam, where were you, that I miss'd you last Night, at the Park?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Did you shine there last Night?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Madam, I did; for after I had pranc'd before your Window upon my Roan-Nag, in honour to my Love,—
Did you see me Madam?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: O Sir, my Eyes met you in your Career, by the same token you had a Muskatoon and Pistols.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I had so Madam, and my man carry'd a skrew'd Gun, that I bought at Brussels; for I alwayes love to do those things en Cavalier; but thus equipped, I went to take the Air in the Park, and immediately all the Ladies and Persons of Quality left the Tour and came about me, and were most incomparably pleas'd with the fashion; so that I am resolv'd next time to go with Back, Breast, and Head-Piece.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Most accutely imagin'd.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: But hark you Madam, yonder are my Fiddles: I bespoke 'em, and pray let me have the honour to dance with you; it may be you will like my manner well enough.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: But we want Women.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I'll supply that, Madam, immediately.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Prethee do, and make haste Crazy.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Now will I be reveng'd upon Briske, and bring his own Strumpet hither.—

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: You must not deny me this Evening some private Conference with you.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: But how shall I keep it from the knowledge of my Niece.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Madam, If you please to walk in the Garden, I'll come in at the Back-door and wait on you there, where we will confer about our mutual happiness.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: I will not fail—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: My honourable Aunt that shall be, I adore your Shoe-strings.

sp.speaker: La. Lou.
sp.p: O Lord Sir, your Servant. Come on Mr. Raymund, let's hear you break a jest, and put these two Wits out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Methinks Mr. Drybob is a notable man.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, as far as Inns of Court breeding; but alas, we are above those things.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Are you above Inns of Court breeding?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Yes, that I am Sir, what's that to you?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Why it is not six Moneths since you us'd to keep Company with none but Clerks, and call for your Three-pence in Beef at Hercules Pillars or the Harrow in Chancery-Lane; where the whole Company us'd to fall out about the dividing of Three-half-pence: when every Night you us'd to drink Ale and put Law Cases as long as you could see.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: You are merry Sir.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: And where you us'd—

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Nor is it five Moneths since I saw you strut most Majestically in the Hall and inveagle a third man at Six-penny In and In, and by the help of a dozen men, chastiz one poor Topper or Palmer; where I have seen you most magnanimously assist at the 〈◊〉 of a Bawd, or the washing and trimming of a Baily.
Where I have seen you?—
Is this your breeding?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: A pox on't a man cannot speak for you.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: But Sir, I'd have you know I was as well esteem'd there as any man that ever eat Loyns of Mutton dry-rosted yet, and danc'd as well at the Revels too.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: I have seen you there, how you—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: And let me tell you that at Christmass, when we were to have had a Prince, I was as fair for preferment as any man there.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Yes, and I can tell you—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: But the Government, by reason of some civil dissentions, fell that Christmass to a Common-wealth; but alas I am above these things.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Above 'em!— I'll tell you—

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Why this to me?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Pox of these uncivil fellows, they won't let a man break a jest among 'em; and Madam, I am the Son of a Baboon, if stoppage of Wit be not as great a pain to me as stoppage of Urine.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Have not I seen you within these three Moneths lolling out of Mundens with a Glass of Windy-Bottle-Ale in one hand and a Pipe of Mundungus in the other; and out of a brisk gay humor, drinking to Passengers in the Street.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: 'Tis well Sir, I hope you will give me satisfaction for these affronts?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Yes, as much as you dare ask.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Then blood will ensue.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Madam, here is one Lady.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Death this Rogue has undone me! Friske here! Theodosia will for ever disown me—

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: What's the matter Briske? are you Planet struck. Crazy, I could hugge thee for this.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: We need your assistance in a Dance, Madam.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Your Servant sweet Madam; Lord, Mr. Brisk, you need not be so strange.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ah Cosin your Servant.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Is she your Cosin Sir?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Mr. Brisk is none of my Cosin, I assure your Ladyship; is my Servant, nay perhaps there is a little nearer relation betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: How's this Sir?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: 'Slife, this She Devil will ruin me! Alas, Madam, she's merry, she drolls; but come let 's dance and put these things out of our heads. Come in Mi●…m and Crotchet and fegue your Violins away, fa, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: O Heaven! who's here, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: This is a Revenge beyond my expectation, stand by Crazy; whither do you put the Lady? Come in Mrs. Striker; here's a Mistriss of Crazy's will serve to make up the number of Dancers, Madam.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Prethee begone, if thou lov st me.

sp.speaker: Striker.
sp.p: Come Mr. Crazy, this won't pass upon me. Your Ladysh ps most obedient Servant—

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Bear up Crazy, you know she's a Person of Honour.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Come Fiddles strike up, p ay Madam, let's dance.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Now Sir, I hope you are ready to give me satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I am Sir.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Fo low me then Ladies, I have an inexorable business calls me away at present— Servant, your Se vant.

sp.speaker: Raym
sp.p: Ladies, I'll wait on you agen instantly; Mrs. Bridget prethee forget not what I said to you, we shall have excellent sport.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I warrant you I'd do't Sir.

sp.speaker: La. L v.
sp.p: Now he's gone, I'll retire; Ladies and Gentlemen you Se v nt—

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: O me, Madam, why does not your Ladyship frequent the Mulberry Garden, oftner: I vow we had the pleasant'st D vertisement there last night.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Ay, I was there, Madam Frisk, and the Garden was very ful; Madam, of Gentlemen and Ladies that made love together till Twelve a lock at Night, the prettyly'st: I vow 'twould do ones heart good to see them.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Why that's a time for Cats to make love in, not Men and Women.

sp.speaker: Frisk
sp.p: Well Madam, there was a Lord, that shall be nameless, would needs come and proffer his service to me.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: I know who that was; alas, he'll do that to any body, Madam Friske.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Lord, you are so troubl'd, I warrant you, Madam Striker.

sp.speaker: D y●….
sp.p: But are thou sure thy Mistriss loves me?

sp.speaker: B●…idg.
sp.p: Why she cannot rest for you.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: But she's so pester'd with these Fools Brisk and Crazy, that I can have no-time to ca ress her.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I'll tell you a way to get privately, into her Chamber this Night.

sp.speaker: Frisk
sp.p: But Madam, this Lord took me by the hand and kiss d it, and told me it was as sweet as Roses and as soft as Jelly of Quinces.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Or he might have said as sweet as Frankincence or as soft as the Pappe of an Apple.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, that's nothing; I assure your Ladyship, he has said the same thing to me twenty times.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: For my part, Madam Striker, I do not think you know him.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Lord, Madam Friske, you are alwayes detracting from one, I am sure I saw him last Night, and he told me, Madam, he honour'd the ground I trod upon, and made me abundance of the rarest Complements, and I said a number of the pretty'st things to him; if I could remember, I'd tell 'em your Ladyship, you shou'd be judge of them, Madam.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Bridget accept of this little Present, I'll not fail to do it— Ladies I have an exorbitant affair causes me at present to bestow my absence upon you, but I'll besure not to fail you—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: What means this foolish fellow?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Crazy let me beg a word with you.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Madam, now she talks thus, there was another Person of Quality came to me, and told me I was a pretty Nymph, and he was a Satyr, and invited me to drink a Bottle of Rhenish and Sugar, and I protest and vow he would not drink one drop, till I had dipt my Finger in the Glass.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: It seems he lov'd to drink with a Tost—

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Pish! that's nothing, I assure you a Person of Quality, that treated me, would not drink a drop of Wine, till I had wash'd my hands in the Glass, now she talks of that, hah.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: What ridiculous vain Wenches are these?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Pish! mind her not Madam, but I vow, now she puts me in mind on't, a Gentleman t'other day play'd the Wagg with me, and would needs pull my Shoe off my Foot and drink it full of Wine; upon my word he did now.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Faith, as thou say'st, I believe she loves me; but why would she not tell me this her self?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: She had no opportunity, but she charg'd me to desire you to come in at her Window this Night as I tell you.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: And upon my honour I'll do't, wer't as high as Pauls. Ladies, my occasions invite me hence, and I shall be glad to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Madam, I humbly covet the honour of your further acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I hope your Ladyship will not deny me that honour.

sp.speaker: Frisk and Strik.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Madam, I'll not fail you upon my honour.—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: What means this fellow? Bridget, what trick have you put upon these two Coxcombs, that they both tell me they will not fail me.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Madam, Mr. Raymund designs this Night privately to wait on you, and that he may not be interrupted, has appointed my Lady to wait for him in the Garden; and I to get rid of this brace of Widgeons, have appointed each of 'em to get in at your Window by Ladders privately this Night.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: How then shall I see Raymund in my Chamber without discovery?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Madam, I have appointed them to come to a wrong Window, but were it the right Window, they being to come both at one time, would disappoint one another.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: That's not unpleasant, we may have good sport. 'Tis possible they may be taken by the Watch, and apprehendded for House-breakers; but come along with me.—

div.head: The Fourth ACT.
div.stage: Enter Raymund and Briske in a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: COme out Sir, and fight, if you have a maw to t: I am ready, I thought you would have brought me into the Field, and you bring me into a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Nay prethee dear Rogue, le'ts stay a little and debate the business over a Bottle of Wine first: Look you, here's to you.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Must I stay, till by the strength of Terse Claret, you have whet your self into courage?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: But look you, dear Raymund, the Case is this—

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: No more words, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Now I think on't better, we must adjourn the Combate, for 'tis grown dark and we cannot see to kill one another.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Come I warrant you we can see one anothers Bodies, and that's enough.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ay, but I have sworn never to fight, but when I can see to parrie.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I'll take away that objection; here are Candles in the Room, and I'll bolt the Door, that no Drawer shall come to part us.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Fie Raymund, is that like men of honour, fight in a Tavern? why 'tis like the Bullies man.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: None of your foolish punctilio's here, draw.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Well, ha, ha, ha, I have consider'd on't, and Gad thou art a very honest fellow, I have that affection for thee, that the Devil take me if I fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Why did you call me out then?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Come, pox on't, put up; I must confess I have rashly embarqu'd my self in a most prejudicial affair, but thou art a man of honour, and I will not fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Are you not a Coward?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ha, ha, honest Raymund, thou art a very merry fellow, I'll give thee leave to say what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I need not ask the question.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Well faith, I will not fight with thee, say what thou wilt, but upon my honour I'll give thee this Diamond Ring and my Roan Nag, if thou'lt oblige me in one thing.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: In what can that be?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: You know my Mistriss will-think I ought in honour to fight; and if you will do me the favour to make her believe you fought with me, I'll tell her you disarm'd me, and by this means I shall save honour, and you will get it; and for ever oblige me.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Faith I had best take 'em for sport sake, though I return 'em again.—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Prethee, dear Rvymund do; I'll do as much for thee upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Would you have a Gentleman lie for you?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Why I'll lie for you agen man, when you will; what do you talk of that?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Not I Sir.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Let me see, I have thought upon a way to save that; look thou, we 'll fight a little in jest; and I'll let you disarm me. 〈◊〉, 〈◊〉 take the Ring, and do't; and I'll send for my Roan Nag 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Come Sir, to oblige you I will, Draw then.—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Honest Raymund, I am thy dear Servant.—

sp.speaker: Raym
sp.p: Come on, come, have at you—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Hold hold man— hold—

sp.speaker: Raym
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: How shall I be sure you won't fight in earnest?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I give my word for't.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: But Gad now I think on't, I won't trust you, if you wou'd give me your Bond; I don't know how the Devil may tempt you: Besides, who knows, but your foot may slip, and you may run me thorow the Body.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: What an immoderate Coward is this?

sp.speaker: Brik.
sp.p: Faith, thou had'st as good tell her so without this Experiment!

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: But there must appear some signs of fighting, or she'll not believe it.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Why I'll tear my Band and my Shirt, and run my self thorow the Coat.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: But there must be some sign of blood.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Pox on't, how shall we contrive that?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Why take your Sword, and run your self thorow the Arm.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Thank you for that i'faith, I have known men have dy'd of that.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Fie, Fie! 'tis nothing; I'll do't my self then.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Hold, hold, 'Slife you may prick an Artery and bleed to death, and then I shall be hang'd for that.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: That's well thought on! O incomparable Coward!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: 'Twill do as well if my Shirt be bloody at the hand, and I'll venture to prick my fingar for that; and to run thorow my Coat.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Well, as you will; but do't as you go along.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Dear Raymund kiss me, you have oblig'd me so, that I am a Son of a Scavenger, if I die without issue, I'll make you my Heir: but if you love me, not a word of all this.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I warrant you. Drawer to pay.

sp.speaker: Brisk
sp.p: Prethee, by no means, Gad I'll treat thee dear Rogue; 'tis all mine. Come on, dear Raymund, let's go—

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: This is the Window Mrs Bridget appointed to get in at, so now to my Climbing.—
How I shall laugh at my two too 〈◊〉 Riv ●…s Brisk and Drybob poor 〈◊〉, that they could not find all this 〈◊〉 how Theodosia abuses them.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: This is the Window, my expectation is on Tiptoes, as I may so say, but let me fix my portable pair of Stairs.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Heaven! what will become of me? This is some Villain coming to commit Burglary.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Pox ta e me, if I know what is the matter; it cannot be the 〈◊〉 that yields thus.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Slife if it should be a Thief, he'll cut my Throat, least I should discover him; what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Well, let what will come on't, though I precipitate my fate, I will storm this i chanted Castle.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Who e'r he be, I am sure I'll not suffer him to come up; if he be a mortal man, I'll try if he has a Neck to spare, for I am resolv'd to break one for him—

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p:
‛ Slife! what's this, am I to be turn'd off and executed for Love felony before my time? what can this mean? I have got no hurt yet: it may be 'twas the corner of the Balcony I set my Ladder
against: I'll make one experiment more: so now, 'tis fast.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Theodosia, Theodosia, open your Window.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: The Ladder stands very fast now, I will once more enterprize this honourable action, though Belzebub himself stood in my way— Theodosia open your Window, 'tis I my Dear.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Death, what will become of me, this must be the Devil, a Man would have broke his Neck.
O Heaven! yonder is a Light coming towards us. I shall be ruin'd if I don't shift for my self.

sp.speaker: Dryb
sp.p: If I be discover'd by yon Ignis fatuus or Lanthorn, I shall be undone for ever, I must try to make an escape.

div.stage: Enter Raymund and Brisk, Boy with a Light and Fiddles; and beat them as they come down the Ladder.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Come on my dear Friend, strike up my Men of Noise; How now! what's hete? Thieves with Ladders at my Mistrisfes Window, I'll mall 'em.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: How now Villains— Bridget has done this admirably.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: 'Slife Raymund, if I had not come, I might have lost my Mistriss out of this Window; for on my Conscience these Rogues came with a felonious intention: but come let's in and give 'em an account of it: and Fiddles make way for us.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Come on: But how shall I get rid of this Fool, I must think of some way.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: O Gentlemen! what's the cause of this uproar?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Oh, Mrs. Bridget, I have made bold to beat a couple of Rascals; that were going to commit Felony, without the benefit of the Clergy; but I'll go and wait upon my Mistriss

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Oh, Mrs. Bridget, 'twas Crazy and Drybob, our Plot is spoil'd; I shall be diverted by them from seeing my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: No, no, let me alone, I'll dispose of 'em another way.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Adieu—

div.stage: Enter Crazy from behind the Door.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Oh I am beaten, bruis'd, and lam'd so, that I had rather have been twice flux'd than have endur'd it; my bones are as loose as the Skeletons in the Physick School: Oh my Head and Shoulders! Mrs. Bridget I kiss your hands, and rest your humble Servant Crazy.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Sir, I find you are defeated by some ill accident or other, but I'll put you in another way to be secure. The Lady Theodosia is in that passion for you, that I fear she will discover her self.

sp.speaker: Craz
sp.p: Poor heart! I know she loves me; but I hope she will be so discreet as to conceal her passion; but here was another with a Ladder climbing up to the Window, or I had got in.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Another! that's impossible; but least you should be suspected, take away your Ladder, and set it against the Garden Wall, and I will appoint your Mistriss to receive you there; if you will venture to come over to her; and there shall be a Parson ready to joyn you in the Banquetting-house: make haste, least you be surpriz'd, and come to us instantly.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Bridget take this, I flie, I flie.—

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: O Mrs. Bridget! Are you there? I have been beaten more severely than ever Turk was by Tamberlain; which by the way is no ill comparison, hah?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I have heard so; but take up your Ladder and be gone, and lay it down on the back-side of the house and come to us presently, and I will design an easier assignation for you; haste, lest you be discover'd.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Bridget take this Ring, I'll be with you instantly.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Go your wayes you brace of Baboons, and be still the subject of all Farces—

div.stage: Enter Raymund, Briske, La. Loveyouth, Theodosia, Bridget.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Is it possible! Thieves coming in at my Window! Heaven! how I tremble!

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Truly Madam, they were as sufficiently beaten as your Ladyship can wish.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: That's some revenge for the trouble their impertinence has given me, but I am afraid these Coxcombs will hinder Mr. Raymunds Visit.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Fear not that, Madam.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Be not apprehensive Madam, for the Rascals are too well satisfi'd for their pains to attempt any more.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Ladies and Gentlemen, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Dear friends, your Slave; I am in one word the Enemy to all your Foes.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Oh are you here! I'll tell you as I was coming in to give my Mistriss a Serenade, a couple of Felonious Rascals were with two Ladders climbing in at a Window of the House; but I think I have so bruis'd the Dogs, they'l scarce be fit for climbing this Week agen.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: A plague on't, I feel it in my bones, but I must dissemble it.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Pox on them, the Rogues laid on as if they had been threshing for Twelve Pence a day.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: But is it possible?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Yes, I assure you as this Blade doth testifie.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Why, what impudent Rogues were these Crazy?

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: ‛ Death, that I must be forc'd to call my self so.— If I had been there I would have mall'd the Villains.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: For my part I don't wish I had been there, for my extraordinary passion would have made me had the blood of the Rogues; that's certain.— O pox of their heavy hands.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: He has been fighting, Madam, that's the truth on't; pray take notice on't.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I wonder, Raymund, no body takes notice of my torn Band, my bloody Sleeve, and my Coat being run thorow, I think they are all blind.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Good lack, Mr. Brisk, you are bloody and your Band's torn.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ha! bloody say you?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Pray hold up the humor, Madam.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I protest, Sir, you fright me, what dangers have you run your self into?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, this is nothing, a trifle, a trifle.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Your Coat's run through, you have been fighting.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: My Coat run through! where, where? ha, ha, 'tis so.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: A pox on him this damn'd Bully Heildibrand was flesh'd, and would needs shew his Valour upon my Shoulders.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Are you wounded Sir?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: 'Pshaw Madam, this, alas, alas, I beseech you take no notice of this; ' pshaw, a slight thing, a toy, fa, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Shall I go for a Surgeon?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: No, I thank you, he'd discover the trick on't; no, no, by no means; alas, you make so much on't: I am us'd to these things; ' pshaw, this is nothing: Pray call in the Fiddles, come, come; let us be very merry, fa, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Sweet Mr. Briske do me the favour to tell me the occasion of this?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing, Madam, alas, alas,—

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Assure your self I'll not fail to wait for you in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I hope your Ladyship doubts not me.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Faith Madam, if you will needs have it, I made bold to call Mr. Raymund to an account for some words that passed before you; and upon my honour, Madam, he's a very gallant fellow.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech you Mr. Brisk.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Nay, Gad it shall all out, he fought like Thunder and Lightning, and I must confess it was my fortune to be disarm'd, Madam; but I hope I lost no honour, since 'twas by so brave a
fellow, whom for his generosity I embrace. Dear Friend, you have oblig'd me for ever. Come Fiddles strike up, I have provided a very honest fellow to dance.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Madam, I'll not fail to wait on you, your humble Servant.—

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Madam, I hope you will be punctual.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Trust me Sir.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Adieu to all.—

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Madam, I'll instantly go and prepare to wait on you, you'l not fail.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I shall not be so injurious to my self.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I humbly kiss your hands. Madam, your Ladyships most obedient Servant.—

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Good night, sweet Mr. Crazy; Mr. Brisk, I pray be pleas'd to favor me with your absence.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: 'Pray do, and get a Surgeon to dress you, and to morrow I shall be ready to receive a Visit.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ladies your Servant, Servant, Ladies, fa la, la, la.—

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Pray Gentlewoman go up into your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Madam, I'll obey.—

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Be sure you do.—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Go thy ways, my dear Aunt, and meditate on what thou'lt ne'r enjoy— If my Uncle, after all this report of his being kill'd, should appear agen, when she has, as she thinks, made sure of another Husband, it would be no ill Farce.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Now, now, my Incomparable Theodosia, I am blest with the opportunity I have so long sought for to cast my self at your feet, and to tell you, that it belongs to you to make my life for ever happy or miserable.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: You may with justice enough accuse me of levity, in so suddenly granting it; but I hope you have so much honour, to impute my easiness somewhat to the slavery I suffer, though I have no disesteem of you.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Madam, It is so much to my advantage, that I shall never enquire the Cause, only let me beg of you, since our fortune is like to allow us so few of those opportunities, that we may make what use we can of this.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I have so absolute a confidence in your honour, that I yield to you conduct in this affair, and defire nothing more than to be redeem d from the foolish Tyrany of my Aunt.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I have left my Lady in the Garden, most impatiently expecting you Mr. Raymund. But pray Madam, if you love me, retire into your Chamber, lest any of the Servants should unluckily see you, and inform your Aunt.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: ‛ T is is no ill advice.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: But how have you dispos'd of Drybob and Crazy.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: O they are safe enough, Sir.

div.stage: Enter La. Loveyouth in the Garden.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Sure the passion he has for me, will not suffer him to stay long, the Story of Thieves at my Window, has put me into such a fright, that nothing but Love could engage me to walk here alone.

div.stage: Enter Crazy looking over the Wall.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: The Coast is clear on this side, if my Mistriss be but in the Garden, I am safe— My Dear.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Here I am.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Now I come, wer't as high as Grantham Steeple! Death I have broke both my Shins: I am murder'd: Oh I see these leaps are not for men that have flux'd thrice.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: How Mr. Raymund! Have you hurt your self?

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Did you expect Raymund here? I am not he.

div.stage: Enter Drybob looking over the Wall.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Now for my leap of honour.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! Thieves, thieves, help, help.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Death what do I here?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Thieves! I shall be apprehended for a House-breaker.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Where shall I hide my self? I would not be discover'd for the World.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: I am astonish'd like the Head of a Gorgon; what shall I do to abscond a little, I shall be apprehended for a Thief else.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: 'Tis very dark, where shall I hide my self?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: What Devilish mistake is this? Pox o'this damn'd post, I am sure I had like to get a most Diabolical fall with running against it.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Death what was that I run against, what an unfortunate fellow am I, to be thus disappointed, just as I thought to have been sure of my Mistriss? but my comfort is, I know she loves me.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: What a Devillish Catastrophe is this?—

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: O horrid! sure this House is haunted, which way can I scape?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: If this be the Devil that touch'd me, I don't like his slie Tricks to fright a man thus; would he would be as civil as the Wiltshire Devil was: and beat a Drum, to give a man notice where he is, that I might avoid him, unless he were better company.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: What's here? her amazement hath made her leave open the Door of the House, I'll in there, there's more safety yet than here—

sp.speaker: Dryb
sp.p: Ha, I saw one enter at that Door, I'll follow and apprehend him; and his attachment will secure me.—

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: What Door is this? I'll e'en hide my self here till this hassle be over.
sp.stage: Noise within. Lights here, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: If I could but conceal my self till they are past, I might easily insinuate my self into Theodosia's Chamber. What's here? This I believe leads into the Cellar, I will descend and lie in Ambush there.—

div.stage: Enter Servants with Torches, Spits, and Fireforks, Mr. Sneake and Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: Come, now we have muster'd up our forces, let's into the Garden.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Ay, come let's see who this Devil is my Lady speaks of; we shall find more than one I believe.

sp.speaker: 2. Serv.
sp.p: I believe we shall find them to be Thieves.

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: If it be the Devil, Mr. Parson, we'll turn you loose to him, you take pay to fight against him; we are but Volunteers.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: If he dares approach, I will conquer him syllogistically in Mood and figure, and conjure him down with

lg.l: Barbara Celarent Darii, Ferioque Darapti.
Cesare, Camestres, &c.

sp.speaker: 2. Serv.
sp.p: Hold, hold, 'slife this is the way to raise him:

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: I think your best way is to take the great Bible in the Hall, and fling at his head; that will knock him down certainly.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Come, let's in quickly, if they be Thieves, they'l escape else.—

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: The Cellar Door is open, if there be any body there, we'll lock it and secure 'em—

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: How unlucky is this! this has marr'd all our design; my Lady has found Mr. Raymund and her Niece, we are undone beyond redemption.

div.stage: Enter La. Loveyouth, Raymund, and Theodosia.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: False and ungrateful man, did I for this, so soon bestow upon you my too credulous heart, so early to betray me; O unheard of Villany.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Madam, pray hear me.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: No, thou vile treacherous man, I will hear no more, Hast thou the impudence to excuse it! O heaven! I am lost for ever. But for you, you most abominable Creature, to undermine me thus: Take leave of liberty, hence forwards your Chamber shall be your Prison, till I have dispos'd of you to another Person, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Then Madam, you force me to declare my self sooner than my Modesty would give me leave; this Gentleman is mine while I have breath; nothing but death shall part us.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: And Madam, that minute that I am false to you, may all the plagues that e'r afflicted yet mankind fall on me.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: In what a miserable condition am I? but Mr. Raymund I cannot believe this, sure this is some enterlude.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Madam, it is a truth I'll die for, though Madam, I am oblig'd to beg your Ladyships pardon for making you a property.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: O impudence! Come Mistriss into your Chamber quickly, I'll be your Keeper.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Madam, we will be pris'ners together.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Out of my Doors, you Villain, or I will have those that shall chastise your insolence with death.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Madam, I haven t so mean a soul, to be frighted from protecting my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Sir, Let me entreat you to leave me, and assure your self we will not long be separated.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: But Madam, 'twill be dang'rous to leave you to her fury.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Sir, Let me beg you will not dispute it further, but be gone; if you should make more noise in this business, it might call my honour in question.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Madam, I must obey, and I have a way to free you instantly, 'tis this.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Away, no more discourses.—

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Well, a desperate disease must have a desperate Cure; Mrs. Bridget I have a way this moment to secure my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: O Sir, I am in that fright for you.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: within. Bridget come up quickly.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: O Sir, I am call'd I must away.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I have not time to tell you; but desire Theodosia, whatever happens not to be frighted, I'll about it instantly.

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: My Lady was frighted with nothing.

sp.speaker: 2. Serv.
sp.p: If any body had been there, the Walls are so high on the inside, they could not have 'scap'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: Ha, here's one, seize him.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Seize me, you Rascals; have at you.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Nay, now you are in Combat, I'll leave you—

sp.speaker: 2. Serv.
sp.p: This a Thief, I am sure he fights like a Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis Mr. Raymund, did you not know him.

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: A pox on him, was't he? but let 's to my Lady, and give her an account.—

div.stage: Enter Crazy and Drybob in the Cellar.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I hear a bustling here about the Cellar that frights me horribly! This is a most unfortunate night.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: O that I were out of this Hellish Place! if ever I had to do with Love and Honour more, would I were an Eunuch in the Turks Seraglio.— Oh Heaven, who's that there?

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: 'Tis a man by his asking that Question, and may be one of the House.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Who are you in the Name of Wonder? O how I dissolve!

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I am the Devil.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: The Devil! oh he's come to fetch me away for my whoring and my drinking.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Mortal, thou art my due.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: That may be, but he's a damn'd impatient Devil to dun before his day.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Come into my Arms.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: O Heaven, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: 'Slife fire! Oh Heaven! how shall we get out?

sp.speaker: Craz
sp.p: groping. Which is the way out? The Door's lock'd, what shall I do? They'll not mind us if we call; we shall be burnt.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: What are you a Devil, and afraid of your own Element? Methinks a Devil out of the Fire should be like a Fish out of the Water.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Fire, fire, fire.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Help, help here, fire, murder, help.

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: What noise was that below?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Help, help.

sp.speaker: 2. Serv.
sp.p: Oh ho, have we caught you? They are the Thieves.

sp.speaker: 1.. Serv.
sp.p: That's well, stay there; you Dogs, if the House be burnt, I'll assure you, you shall burn with it.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: O help, help, 'tis Crazy.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Crazy! a Curse on you for frighting me; help, 'tis I Drybob.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: We'll see if we can get out at the Window. Well this is a judgment upon me for acting the Devil.—

div.stage: Enter Servants running up and down.

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: More hands, water quickly, and we shall quench it instantly.

sp.speaker: 2. Serv.
sp.p: 'Tis strange how the Coach-House shou'd be fir'd.—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: This was an excellent Stratagem, Sir, and with little or no danger.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Come Madam, while your Aunt is seeing the fire quench'd on the back-side, let us escape at the fore-door.—

div.stage: Enter La. Loveyouth, Bridget, Sir Richard, Sneak, and Servants.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: So, Heaven be thanked, all danger's past; How could this fire happen? This has been a night of wonder.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I will dilucidate it to you, you saw a Spirit in the Garden, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: I did, I think, to my great astonishment; I have not yet recover'd the fright.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, These Philosophers aver, that all Spirits are transported through the Air in their several and respective Vehicles; now this was infernal, and had a Bituminous Vehicle, which by a violent Motion against the Coach-House, as it were by Collision, did generate this Flame, which had like to have caus'd this Conflagration.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: A pox o' this Fustian Rascal.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Come Madam, it must be some Thieves design to rifle your house.

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: We have some of the Thieves safe in the Cellar, they shall-suffer for it.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: In the Cellar, fetch 'em up quickly; by them we may discover something. Go see where my Niece is Bridget.

sp.speaker: 2. Serv.
sp.p: Come along you Rascals.

div.stage: Enter Servants haling Crazy and Drybob.

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: Come out you Sons of Bitches.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Who are these Mr. Crazy and Mr. Drybob? this is as strange as all the rest.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Madam, I kiss your fair hands.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Pish, that's a vile old phrase. I am an humble Servant of your Footmans.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Sure this is inchantment! How came you two in the Cellar?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Madam, I will most expeditiously inform you.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: How now, where's my Niece?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Madam, She's gone! fled away! I have been in every Room of the House and cannot find her.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Gone! What can this mean?

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Gone! I am undone! Ruin'd for ever! What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: She undone! Oh invincible impudence!

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: What imports this transport of yours, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: You and I and all of us are abus'd! betray'd! this false Wretch, this base Villain Raymund, has stol'n away my Niece.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I see Raymund is a man of honour. This pleases me.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Madam, Do not fear that, to my knowledge there is a person in the world, she is more than half engag'd to. No, no, she cares not for Raymund, take that from me.

sp.speaker: L. Lov.
sp.p: Flatter not your self, 'tis true, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Raymund! I'll assure you Madam, she us'd to simper more favourably upon me than upon any man, and gad if the truth were known, she thinks me all the Nine Worthies, compar'd to him.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, Let's in and hear the Story, while I send for a Warrant to search for my Niece; I'll have her dead or alive.—

div.head: The Fifth ACT.
div.stage: Enter La. Loveyouth, Bridget, and Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: NO News of either Raymund or Theodosia?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: All possible search has been made after 'em both last night and this morning, and they are neither to be found.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: How am I confounded with this disaster; yet I have it in my head to be reveng'd on 'em both.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Your Ladyship was too credulous to trust him so soon.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: And Robin, he's a dirty person thus to desert me; but I'll be quit with him, and that Jig-em-bob my Niece.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: How Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Why, I will immediately settle my Estate, to which she is Heir, for want of lawful Issue of my Body, on my Cosin Richard, and to plague Raymund I will marry another; for I am resolved to play at a small game rather than stand out.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Oh unparallel'd impudence! I'll try her further: Madam, What think you of Mr. Crazy, he is no unfit man for a Husband?

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Why really I believe he is a good natur'd Person and a Child of Honour, the softness and gentleness of his Amorous Nature is admirable; but do you think he will have any sprinklings of affection for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! what do I hear?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Sprinklings, Madam? He will have a whole Flood of Love for you.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p:
Why truly, he is a pretty hopeful man, and I have no aversion to, but rather a concern for him; you shall see, Bridget, I
am a Woman easie to command my passions; but in the mean time send for a Scrivener, and bid him bring a Blank Conveyance with him: for though I do resolve to make Mr. Crazy my Husband, yet I will dispose of my Estate, as prudent Widdows are wont to do.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: 'Slife! now 'tis time to appear! I shall be finely us'd else by this Villainous Woman. I'll into the Town and prepare for't.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam, Mr. Crazy is coming to wait on you.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Tell him I am retir'd. Bridget, I'll leave thee to sound him as to point of this Concern.—

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: This is pleasant, I'll observe him.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Murder, murder. O Heaven! what shall I do? I have hurt my self just upon the Shin-bone, that was exfoliated: I have spoil'd my Arm: I fell just upon that part of my Arm, where is a Callous Node upon the Periostium.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: What's the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I have hurt my self a little with the fall; besides I am in a little disorder for the loss of Theodosia; sure some base fellow has forc'd her hence; for I am sure she lov'd me most extreamly. 'Sdeath I have spilt my Bottle of Diet-drink in my Pocket, and spoil'd all my Almonds and Raisins.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Flatter not your self, Mr. Crazy; she loves you not.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Prethee do not put this upon me; ha, ha, ha. I am sure no man had those favourable smiles from her that I received. Oh! that twinge.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Come, the truth is, Sir, she is fled away with Mr. Raymund.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Lord, Mrs. Bridget! all this won't do; as if I did not know when a Woman loves me?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: You may please to slight it; but to my knowledge she is marry'd to Mr. Raymund.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Is it true?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Too true for you.—

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I am ruin'd beyond redemption, I am for ever disappointed both of Love and Money.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: There is another person in the world that's worth your Love, and has a Fortune equal to Theodosia.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Dear Soul, thou do ' st eternally oblige me! but prethee who is't? Oh, oh, prethee tell me.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: My Lady Loveyouth.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, well really she is a fine person, and I am extreamly deceiv'd, if she has not a violent and most predominant passion for me.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Sir, You are not deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I think not— I would forgive a Woman that can deceive me in that point.— But where is she?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: In her Chamber, where I am sure you would be no unwelcome person.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: This is very lucky, by this means I shall be fully reveng'd for the most perfidious Apostacy of Theodosia, and with this ample fortune patch up my own ruinous condition.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: No more, Sir, but go to my Lady while she is in this humor.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I am happy beyond expression in your Friendship; alas, I know this poor thing loves me dearly; and gad she shall be no loser by it: I will go immediately and kiss my Ladies hand; but in the mean time receive this little piece of my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Sweet, dear Rogue, I kiss thy pretty hand.—

lg.l: How now?
Is the stray Lady return'd home?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: No Sir, there's no news of her?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: I am the unlawful Off spring of a Jugler, if ever man of honour encounter'd such a Crocodile; and yet let me not live, if she had not the most pretty harmonious strain of wit with her that evet tempted a judicious Ear.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: But she is false— she is false.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Really I begin to conjecture it, yet she has so many predominant perfections with her, which I did adore; that I can scarce invite this into my belief: Invite it— 'faith that's well enough too.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: 'Tis too true.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Well she is gone, adieu to her; yet really she had the prettiest Figures and the choicest Phrases in her ordinary Conferences: there are not better in Pharamond, or Cleopatra.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I am glad to see you so indifferent.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Not so indifferent: Gad I admire the sharpness of her Ingenuity— But I'll tell thee the truth I have sent my man to a little Rosicrucian or Star-gazer; to enquire of my Star how she comes thus to start from her Sphere: Start from her Sphere, that is well now; that is well.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: And when will he return?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: I expect him at every pulse of my Watch; and by the way is not that pretily said— 〈◊〉— But I hope I shall recover her, and yet if I lose her, I am 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 if I have not as many Mistrisses as I can turn my self too: Faith I have abundance of Ladies that would think themselves happy to enjoy me: but I cannot be in all places at once: yet in good faith I wish my self an Ubiquitary for their Love, as I am an honest man.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I am calld, adieu Sir.—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: How now! What's the News? Has Raymund stole away Theodosia— ha.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Ay pox on him, he, or some damn'd Robber as bad as he, that I fear by this time have committed Burglary upon her Body.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: And shall I be thus cheated of my Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Your Mistriss— ha, ha, ha, you speak as freely of her as if you were acquainted ever since the Deluge with her.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Why, had you any pretence to her?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Yes Sir, that I had, and perhaps no man receiv'd larger testimonies of her innate affection.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Oh impudence! why sure you don't pretend to be a man fit for Ladies Conversation! What Charms have you to attract 'em? Ha, ha, ha, you—

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: What Charms quoth he? Is any man in Europe more notorious among Ladies, or valu'd for his pregnant parts, than Drybob? My manner of speaking, if it were nothing else, is enough to intoxicate Ladies affections. No Orator in Christendom adorns his Language with those Flowers that I do, or is inrich'd with more plentiful Discourse.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ad autre Monsieur ad autre.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Ne'r tell me Sir, The Ladies of the Town are so exorbitantly pleas'd with my manner of speaking, that I have been often set upon a Table to speak ex tempore to a whole Room full, and have ravish'd 'em all for half an hour together; and this I have got by University Learning and Travelling.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Fiddle, faddle on your Travelling and University.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I protest you make me smile.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: You talk of Ladies, I am a man that still flourish in the Spring of all the Fashions, and in such variety that upon my honour 'tis not a fortnight since the publishing of my last new Suit.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Publishing! Pox o'this Rogue! how came he to lite upon that prety expression.—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: You visit Ladies! Gad I spend more money in a year to keep my self sweet, than thy revenue comes to.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: I am the Son of a Lancashire Witch, if thou art not an errant stinking Fellow then; but what do such people signifie but to maintain Fools, Whores, Mercers, Barbers, and Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Look you Sir, I care not a farthing for your frumps; what can you do? I can sing or walk a Corant with any man in Europe, fa, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: As I hope ever to live to eat Woodcocks, this is a most stupendious Baboon. Pshaw, what d'ee talk of this? Can you break a Jest or make a Reperté to render your self acceptable to Persons? That ought to be the business of all Gentlemen, to take all opportunities of shewing their parts and complying with Company.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Break Jests! Pshaw, no man in Europe better; but I have other wayes to catch Ladies. Look you no man appears better upon a Bench in the Play-House, when I stand up to expose my person between the Acts; I take out my Comb, and with a bonne mien combe my Perriwig to the tune the Fiddles play: thus, look you, fa, la, la, la.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: 'Pshaw, I bear my self at another rate; I sit in judgement upon Playes with my Hat thus; with a brow wrinckl'd like a wither'd Pear-mayne; which Gad is a very pretty thought, take notice of that: but by this posture am I become more dreadful to the Poets and Players then,— What, let me see, pox on't, hum. This is the first time I ever wanted a smile in my life.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Madam, I am transported with your favours.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Why in earnest, Sir, I take you for a Person of Genetosity, and I cannot but comply with your honourable affections.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Madam, I humbly kiss your foot, I will immediately go and prepare for the perfection of my happiness.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Why truly Sir, it is something too sudden and temerarious, but you have so absolute an Ascendant over me, that I cannot signifie any thing as to point of Repulse.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I make bold to take my leave for some few moments.

div.stage: Enter Raymund in disguise and Bridget.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Have you brought a Deed with you?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Yes Madam, such a one as will fit you to a hair.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Let us in and read it.—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Pox on't Mrs. Bridget, thou know'st well enough what's become of Theodosia, prethee tell me.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Well, to you I must confess I do, since she gave me commission to do it; and Sir, the report of Mr. Raymund's stealing her is false: she still preserves her love to you, you are the man she resolves to live and die with.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p:
Dear Rogue bring me to her; faith I was amaz'd to think she should leave me, and betray her self to Raymund, a fellow
that never wore a noble and polite Garniture or a white Perriwig; one that has not a Bit of Interest at 〈◊〉, or ever eat a good Fricacy, Sup, or Rogust, in his life; but prethee bring me to her.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Go immediately to your Lodging, you shall hear from me.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Adieu, Servant Drybob.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Pray will you oblige my understanding, to reveal to it this Mystery.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: 'Tis all for you, in short Theodosia has employ'd me to tell you, that to avoid the importunity of Crazy and Briske, she fled away, but for you she has still the same honour and esteem which you deserve.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: In good faith this thought was no stranger to my imagination.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I have sent him away, that he might not pry into our actions. Hark, my Lady is coming; go instantly and walk in the Piaza, I will send to you suddenly.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: I will, I will—

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I have a plot in this mischievous head of mine, if it takes, shall prove no ill farce.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: What are the Gentlemen gone? Pray call a Servant or two to be witnesses of this Deed of Gift of all my Estate to my Cosin Richard after my decease.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.—

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Remember Mrs. Bridget.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Now I shall fit Theodosia for a punishment for all her villany, by this Deed, shall I not?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Yes, Madam,— better than you imagine.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Oh are you come, Come, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I will put on the Wax, Madam, here's a Deed will match it, and ready fill'd up to my purpose; I have chang'd it without discovery.— Come Madam.

sp.speaker: LaLov.
sp.p: I declare this as my Act and Deed. Come witness it. So,— here Bridget take my Key and lock it up.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Yes, it shall be kept safe,— from you I assure you.—

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: There's for your pains; do's that content you?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I am contented.—

Or all the world can never make me so, to have obtain'd my Theodosia, is a happiness so great, that I could think of nothing beyond that; nor should I have done this, had it not been for her: for I in her have all I e'r would aim at.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: There Sir, there's the Deed.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Bridget, you have oblig'd me beyond a Recompence.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Now you are marry'd to her and have the Writing, pray let the Lady Theodosia come hither instantly, I have more Irons in the Fire, and need her assistance.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: 'Tis well, I ll not fail to tell her—

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Now, dear Madam Bridget, Let our Flames incorporate, and by the Mysterious Union of a Conjugal Knot, beyond the Gordian, too strong for the Macedonian Steel to rescind.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Shall I never learn to understand you, pray help me to a Clavis.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: The meaning of it is I would make you my Spouse.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: What? would you lose your Fellowship?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I would to that, as they say— Nuncium remittere; for I am presented to a Benefice worth six on't.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: You have reason, I shall deny you nothing that's reasonable, upon condition you will do one thing for me.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, I shall not deny it.

lg.l: Post varios Casus post tot discrimina rerum.
Tendimus in Latium—

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: You must first marry Mr. Brisk and Mr. Drybob as I shall direct you, but the Ladies will not be known, therefore you must marry 'em in Vizor Masks.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I will, since you command, make no haesitation or dilatory scruple.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Pray be gone, I see one coming I must speak with; well, this Plot if it takes, will produce no unpleasant effects. Oh Madam!
I am heartily glad your Plot succeeded so well.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Dear Bridget I owe a great deal of it to thee.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I am happy that I could serve you; but now I have a design of my own, in which I beg your Ladyships assistance.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: You may be assur'd of that, what is it?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I have perswaded each of the Coxcombs Briske and Drybob, that you fled to reserve your self for him; and each has so good an opinion of himself, that I found it no hard matter.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: What can this produce to your advantage?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Madam, I 'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Good lack, Madam Striker, who thought to have seen you here▪

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Why, Madam Friske? I hope I may be as welcome here as you can.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I do not know that neither.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Madam, your Ladyships most obedient Servant.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Madam, your Ladyships most affectionate Servant.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Madam, your Ladyships most obliged Servant.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Madam, your Ladyships most faithful and devoted Servant.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Madam, I have weighty occasion invites me to kiss your Ladyships hands this Forenoon.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: And I one of no less consequence, I assure your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I hope your Ladyships will do me the honour to pronounce both your occasions.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Madam, Mine is.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Madam, Mine is.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: I wonder you have no more breeding than to interrupt one.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Marry come up Mrs. Habberdasber! Do you think my Breeding inferiour to yours? I am sure I was bred at a very pretty dancing School hard by, and you talk of that.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Gigg-em-bob! your breeding, ha, ha, I am sure my husband marry'd me from Hackney School, where there was a number of Substantial Citizens Daughters; your Breeding—

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Gill-flirts we live in a fine age, if a little Paltry Citizens Wife shall compare her self with a Person of my Quality, ifaith.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Thy Quality Mrs. Kick-up—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Nay; pray Ladies! Pray keep the peace. Come, have but a little patience, and I will give Audience to both; but no more contention, I am in haste Mrs. Striker.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Madam, I have done; and my business is this: I protest I am almost asham'd to tell you, but it must out: Mr. Crazy has long since engag'd his heart to me and I mine to him, and therefore I think, Madam, your Ladyship ought not to encou rage the falshood of any Ladies Servant, to listen to any proffers of affection from him.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Why, you are marry'd! Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Ay, ay, by that time your Ladyship has been marry'd a year or two, you'll soon find the necessity of a Gallant as well as I; besides my husband's in a Consumption, heaven be prais'd, he cannot live long.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Madam, upon my word I will not rob you of your Jewel, I freely resign him to you.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: What! will you never have done? Madam, Does your Ladyship know that Mr. Briske is my Servant.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and know (and know what you would have) and I have found out a way to get you marry'd to this Servant too, or to another as good.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I humbly thank your Ladyship; indeed I had rather have another, for besides variety in the Case, I shall be then at once provided with a Husband and a Gallant.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Pray take this Key, and go up two pair of Stairs to a Chamber on your left hand and stay there till further order. I warrant you, I'll please you; but at present you must leave me: Be gone.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Madam, I humbly take my leave of your Ladyship, your Servant.—

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Your Servant Madam, I am gone.—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Your Ladyships humble Servant, I'll to my Chamber Bridget, and I'll warrant thee to effect thy design.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Why sure you han't the confidence to take place of me, have you Mrs. Whirliwigg.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Prethee Pusse be quiet, I know what I do.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Avoid you Sttumpet, I am the Mother of Children.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Then stay there thou grave Matron.—

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: She has got it, well I was never so affronted in my life, I could tear her heart out: I'll be reveng'd if I live—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Stay, here! I'll send for the brace of Oafs.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I will, Madam—

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs. Bridget I am thy most obliged Servant, I have found out Mr. Sneake and brought him here along with me, to compleat my happiness in joyning me to your Lady, and upon my honour the whole remainder of my life and love shall be at thy service.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: I am glad it was in my power to oblige my Lady in so fine a Person.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Not so neither, yet I will be bold to say she will not be altogether unhappy in a Husband. Boy, I had forgot, go home, and bring me a Bottle of my Dyet-Drink, or I shall eat no Dinner to day. Come Sir—

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Where's my dear Thodosia?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
