sp.p: She'll instantly be here; now Sir I have time to wish you all happiness.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I thank you, but 'tis a superfluous wish, I have it all already; nothing is yet behind but to make peace with my Lady Loveyouth, whom I really have used ill; and to reward your kindness, in earnest of which, you must receive this small present.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Sir, I am already too well rewarded, the honour of serving you carries that along with it.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: You are too kind; but what possibilities is there of reconciling me to your Lady.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: She is now pretty well appeas'd, and has made choice of another for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Who's that?

My dearest Theodosia, I am so happy in thy love, that 'tis beyond the power of Fortune to oblige me more; I can now look down on those I once have envy'd, and scorn all pleasures in the world but thee.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I can sooner distrust my self than your honour, and cannot but be very easie to believe what I like so well; though my own want of merit would perswade me to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: I find the wisest have still less knowledge of themselves than of others, or you would value more what all men do; your Beauty, Wit, and Vertue, are so admirable, that Nature could have added nothing to you; nor is there one Charm in all the rest of your Sex, that can one moment divide my thoughts from you.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p:
I have so great a belief in your constancy and truth, your words can ne'r confirm me more; therefore let us leave this, and think of some attonement to my Aunt: for my part I know none better than helping her to another for a Husband if we can:
for she longs more for one, than a Son and Heir of one and twenty does for the death of his Father.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Madam, She does not want that, for she and Mr. Crazy have resolv'd, he to be reveng'd of you, and she to be reveng'd of Mr. Raymund, to couple in the Bonds of Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: 'Tis pity to forbid the Banes.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: To Crazy! what has she a mind to practise Physick and Surgery.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: O! yonder comes Drybob and Briske.
Pray Mr. Raymund avoid the room, and enter not till I give you your cue—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: I am come, Madam, according to appointment, and understand your resolutions are to live and die with Jack Briske.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I will no longer conceal my affections! I am so ill us'd by my Aunt, that if you think fit, I will immediately consent to be your Wife; Mr. Sneake shall do it for us.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: How am I exalted! Dear Madam, let it be instantly.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: But I must hide my face, or he'll discover me to my Aunt, and we may be prevented for this time.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: 'Slife, I have thought on 't, you shall put on a Vizor Mask.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: What! will you engross the Ladies Ear?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Pray go and expect me suddenly.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Farewel Drybob, ha, ha, ha! poor sneaking fellow.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Mr. Drybob I will not blush to own my affection to you.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, you need not.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Yonder comes one I must speak with, pray go with Bridget; I have entrusted her with the rest: I will be with you suddenly.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Come, my Dear Bridget, I flie as quick as thought.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Madam I beseech you where 's my Lady?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Oh she's marry'd to Grazy since I saw you, she has made quick dispatch I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: 'S Death and Hell marry'd! Is this truth, Madam?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Ay Sir, but what's the Cause that makes you so concern'd at it?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Have I not reason? Do you know this face?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: O Heaven! my Uncle Sir Rich. Loveyouth.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Cease your wonder Niece, you see the Story of my death was feign'd.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: My dear Uncle! I am infinitely happy to see you once more in this place. This was a happy change.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Niece I rejoyce no less to see thee; thou art improv'd in beauty since I saw thee: but this abominable Woman I for ever banish from my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: But pray Sir, what made you keep your disguise so long after your return?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I ll tell you Niece, but hold I hear some coming hither; I'll with-draw and acquaint you with it.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Come Sir, and I'll bring you to one that will be glad to see you——

div.stage: Enter Crazy, La. Loveyouth, and two Servants.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Now, my dear Lady, I am happy beyond my wishes.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you be not the worse opinionated of me, for your easie Conquest; for I have long had an inclination for you.
sp.stage: Enter Sneak, Drybob and Friske, Briske and Bridget. (Friske and Bridget masked.)
sp.p: How now? whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Madam! your Servant, ha, ha, ha, you little think where Theodofia is?

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Name her not, vile Creature, to run away with Raymund.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: No, no, she did not run away with him. With Raymund quoth she? no, no.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: What does this Fool mean? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Not marry'd to Raymund! how unlucky is this? that I should fool my self into marrying this fellow; I might yet have captivated Mr. Raymund.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Gentlemen, are you both satisfi'd with your marriage?

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Ay, ay. Come, my dear Theodosia, unmask your self, and keep 'em no longer in suspence.

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Sir, I obey you.—

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: ' SDeath and Hell! Who's this? Bridget!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Bridget— ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: O tempora! O mores! Would you serve me thus? I shall not live to endure it, I shall suddenly expire, and 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Now Briske, thou hast marry'd the Chamber-maid▪ I'll prefer thee; I told thee the Mistriss was for my turn: Prethee my dear unmask, ha! Who's this?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Even as you see Sir—

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Death, Fire brands, Devils Damnation,! What's this!

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: My old Mistriss! Prethee Drybob be patient; thou wilt have a Son and Heir of mine shortly; and prethee for my sake take care and see him well educated.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: How now Gentlemen, are you bob'd?

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Madam, We are come to beg your approbation of our Marriage; I humbly beg your pardon for the irregular means I us'd: Pray Madam turn not from us, but give us your consent; since 'tis now too late to prevent it.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Avoid my presence thou impudent fellow, I'll have thee kick'd.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Striker and whispers Mrs. Bridget.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Poor fellows, methinks you look as scurvily as if you were mounting the Pillory with Papers on your backs.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Marry'd say you? Ah false man! have you us'd me thus? Did I for this yield up my honour to you, and you promis'd me to marry me after the death of my Husband; who is in a deep Consumption! Ah villainous man! I will have thee kick'd and beaten.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Drybob, Tell him his Wife has made over all her Estate.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Yet this condition of mine is as good as marrying a Widdow that has made over her Estate, as you have done.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Is this true, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: I must confess I did it to defeat my ungracious Niece of her inheritance.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Give you joy good Mr. Crazy.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: Give you joy good Mr. Crazy.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Madam, your Ladyship is mistaken, it is a Deed of Gift of all your Estate, after your decease, to Theodosia: I have it here.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Madam, I thank your Ladyship: I shall study to deserve it.

sp.speaker: La Lov.
sp.p: Am I thus cozen'd and abus'd?

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: 'Tis I am cozen'd and abus'd.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Go thy ways thou vile man, thou art serv'd right for thy falshood to me.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I'll be reveng'd of her.——
I must tell you, Madam, you are not less disappointed than I am; for I must ingeniously confess I am very much visited with the Pox

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: Pox on him for a Rascal; visited is a very pretty word there i'faith.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: O Heaven! I am undone for ever; this is a most unspeakable disappointment to a Lady! O miserable unfortunate Woman that I am.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: What's the matter Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: Oh I have just now cast my self upon that diseas'd impotent fellow, that walking Hospital Crazy.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Now, Madam, d'e wish your other Husband alive in Candia?

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: No, not so neither; but would I were as fair rid of this Husband, as I was of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: So! I am beholding to her!
I have a way to rid you of this Husband.

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: If you have, you shall command my person and my purse.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: And you shall know that I'll command 'em both.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Sir Richard Loveyouth alive!

sp.speaker: La. Lov.
sp.p: O Heaven! I am ruin'd for ever; there is now no dissembling! all my misfortunes are compleated now.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I am glad you are come to take your Wife agen.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Fond Woman, thy foolishness and vanity, and thy impertinent contentions with me, caus'd my three years absence; and shall make me still continue a stranger to your Conversation: yet you shall never want what e'r befits your Quality: upon the rest of all the Company let no Cloud appear to day.

sp.speaker: Brisk.
sp.p: You are a happy man Crazy.

sp.speaker: Dryb.
sp.p: You have had ill luck with honest Women, Crazy, you had e'n as good stick to Whores.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: I have had worse luck with them I am sure, yet this is better than marrying a Chamber-maid, or Wench big with Child, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Sir, I am a stranger to your repute, and think my self much honoured in the relation I have to you.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: Sir, The honour is wholly on my side.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, I am inform'd of all your Stories, and 'tis wisdom in you to be content, with what you can't redress.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I shall ne'r have Children, I therefore here declare my Niece my Heir.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Sir, I can return nothing but my thanks.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: This day, Sir, I dedicate to my fair Niece and you.

sp.speaker: Raym.
sp.p: You do me too much honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen and Ladies, Let's be merry; we'll have Musick, we'll begin this days jollity with a Dance.

sp.speaker: Craz.
sp.p: Sweet Madam Striker, receive me into your favour; for upon my honour, tho I marry'd her, I intended to reserve the whole stock of my affection for thee.

sp.speaker: Strik.
sp.p: Get thee gone, thou wicked fellow, I will have none of thee; thou hast declar'd thou hast the Disease: Get thee gone, I tell thee I will have thee kick'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, joyn in a Dance.
So, 'tis well.

lg.l: All happ ness to both, and may you be,
From discontents of Marriage ever free,
May all your life be one countinued peace,
And may your Loves each day and hour encrease.—
THe Mighty Prince of Poets, learned BEN,
Who alone div'd into the Minds of Men:
Saw all their wandrings, all their follies knew,
And all their vain fantastick passions drew.
In Images so lively and so true;
That there each Humorist himself might view.
Yet onely lash'd the Errors of the Times,
And ne'r expos'd the Persons, but the Crimes:
And never car'd for private frowns, when he
Did but chastise publick iniquitie.
He fear'd no Pimp, no Pick-pocket, or Drab;
He fear'd no Bravo, nor no Ruffian's Stab.
'Twas he alone true Humors understood,
And with great Wit and Judgment made them good.
A Humor is the Byas of the Mind,
By which with violence 'tis one way inclin'd:
It makes our Actions lean on one side still,
And in all Changes that way bends the will.
This—
He onely knew and represented right.
Thus none but Mighty Johnson e'r could write.
Expect not then, since that most flourishing Age,
Of BEN. to see true Humor on the Stage.
All that have since been writ, if they be scan'd,
Are but faint Copies from that Master's hand.
Our Poet now, amongst those petty things,
Alas, his too weak trifling humors brings.
As much beneath the worst in Johnson's Plays,
As his great Merit is above our praise.
For could he imitate that great Author right,
He would with ease all Poets else out-write.
But to out-go all other men, would be
O Noble BEN! less than to follow thee.
Gallants you see how hard it is to write,
Forgive all faults the Poet made to night:
Since if he finn'd, 'twas meant for your delight.
Pray let this find—
As good success, tho' it be very bad,
As any damn'd successful Play e'r had.
Yet if you hiss, he knows not where the harm is,
He'll not defend his Non-sence Vi & Armis.
But this poor Play has been so torn before,
That all your Cruelty can't wound it more.
